chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So today and next Tuesday, we're talking

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: about the role of natural language processing

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: in machine learning in health care.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And this is going to be a heterogeneous kind

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: of presentation.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Mainly today, I'm going to talk about stuff that happened

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: or that takes advantage of methods that are not

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: based on neural network representations.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And on Tuesday, I'm going to speak mostly

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: about stuff that does depend on neural network representations.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: But I'm not sure where the boundary is going to fall.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: I've also invited Dr. Catherine Liao over there,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: who will join me in a question and answer session,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: an interview like we did a couple of weeks ago with David.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Cat is a rheumatologist in the Partners Health Care System.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And you'll actually be hearing about some of the work

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: that we've done together in the past

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: before we go to the interview.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So roughly, the outline of these two lectures

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: is that I want to talk a little bit about why

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: we care about clinical text.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And then I'm going to talk about some conceptually very

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: appealing but practically not very feasible methods that

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: involve analyzing these narrative texts

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: as linguistic entities, as linguistic objects,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: in the way that a linguist might approach them.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And then we're going to talk about what is very often done,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: which is a kind of term spotting approach that says, well,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: we may not be able to understand exactly everything that

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: goes on in the narratives.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: But we can identify certain words and certain phrases that

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: are very highly indicative that the patient has

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: a certain disease, a certain symptom,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: that some particular thing was done to them.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so this is a lot of the bread and butter

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: of how clinical research is done nowadays.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And then I'll go on to some other techniques.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So here's an example.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: This is a discharge summary from MIMIC.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: When you played with MIMIC, you notice that it's de-identified.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so names and things are replaced

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: with square brackets, star, star, star kinds of things.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And here I have re-replaced those with synthetic names.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So Mr. Blind isn't really Mr. Blind.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And November 15 probably really isn't November 15, et cetera.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: But I wanted something that read like real text.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So if you look at something like this,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: you see that Mr. Blind is a 79-year-old white, white male.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So somebody repeated a word with a history of diabetes mellitus

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: in inferior MI who underwent open repair of his increased

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: diverticulum on November 13 at some, again,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: that's not the name of the actual place, medical center.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And then he developed hebatemisis.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So he was spitting up blood and was

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: intubated for respiratory distress.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So he wasn't breathing well.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So these are all really important things

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: about what happened to Mr. Blind.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so we'd like to be able to take advantage of this.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And in fact, to give you a slightly more quantitative

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: version of this, Kat and I worked on a project

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: back around 2010 where we were looking

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: at trying to understand what are the genetic correlates

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: of rheumatoid arthritis.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so we went to the research patient data

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: repository of Mass General and the Brigham Partners

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Health Care.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And we said, OK, who are the patients

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: who have been billed for a rheumatoid arthritis visit?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And there are many thousands of those people.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And then we selected a random set of, I think,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: 400 of those patients.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: We gave them to rheumatologists.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And we said, which of these people

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: actually have rheumatoid arthritis?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So these were based on billing codes.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So what would you guess is the positive predictive value

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: of having a billing code for rheumatoid arthritis

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: in this data set?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: I mean, how many people think it's more than 50%?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: OK, that would be nice.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: But it's not.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: How many people think it's more than 25%?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: God, you guys are getting really pessimistic.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Well, it also isn't.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So it turned out to be something like 19% in this cohort.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Now, before you start calling the fraud investigators,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: you have to ask yourself, why is it

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: that this data is so lousy?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And there's a systematic reason.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Because those billing codes were not

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: created in order to specify what's wrong with the patient.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: They were created in order to tell an insurance

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: company or Medicare or somebody how much of a payment

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: is deserved by the doctors taking care of them.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so what this means is that, for example,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: if I clutch my chest and I'm going to do a blood test,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: is that, for example, if I clutch my chest and go,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: oh, and an ambulance rushes me over to Mass General,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: and they do a whole bunch of tests,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: and they decide that I'm not having a heart attack,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: the correct billing code for that visit

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: is myocardial infarction.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Because, of course, the work that they

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: had to do in order to figure out that I'm not having a heart

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: attack is the same as the work they

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: would have had to do to figure out

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: that I was having a heart attack.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so the billing codes, we've talked about this a little bit

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: before, but they're a very imperfect representation

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: of reality.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So we said, well, OK, what if we insisted

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: that you have three billing codes for rheumatoid arthritis

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: rather than just one?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And that turned out to raise the positive predictive value

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: all the way up to 27%.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So you go, really?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: How could you get billed three times?

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: Well, the answer is that you get billed for every aspirin

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: you take at the hospital.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so, for example, it's very easy

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: to accumulate three billing codes for the same thing,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: because you go see a doctor, the doctor bills you

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: for a rheumatoid arthritis visit.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: He or she sends you to a radiologist

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: to take an X-ray of your fingers, your joints.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: That bill is another billing code for RA.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: The doctor also sends you to the lab

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: to have a blood drawn so that they can

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: check your anti-CCP titer.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: That's another billing code for rheumatoid arthritis.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And it may be that all of this is negative

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: and you don't actually have the disease.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So this is something that's really important to think

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: about and to remember when you're analyzing these data.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And so we started off in this project saying, well,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: we need to get a positive predictive value more

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: on the order of 95%, because we wanted a very pure sample

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: of people who really did have the disease,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: because we were going to take blood samples

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: from those patients, pay a bunch of money to the Broad

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: to analyze them, and then hopefully come up

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: with a better understanding of the relationship

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: between their genetics and their disease.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And of course, if you talk to a biostatistician, as we did,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: they told us that if we have more than about 5% corruption

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: of that database, then we're going to get

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: meaningless results from it.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So that's the goal here.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: So what we did is to say, well, if you

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: train a data set that tries to tell you whether somebody

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: really has rheumatoid arthritis or not based on just codified

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: data, so codified data is things like lab values

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: and prescriptions and demographics and stuff

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: that is in tabular form, then we were

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: getting a positive predictive value of about 88%.

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: And we said, well, how well could we

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: do by instead of looking at that codified data,

chunks.title: Lecture 7 Natural Language Processing (NLP), Part 1
chunks.text: looking at the narrative text in non-coded data?

text: OK. So today and next Tuesday, we're talking about the role of natural language processing in machine learning in health care. And this is going to be a heterogeneous kind of presentation. Mainly today, I'm going to talk about stuff that happened or that takes advantage of methods that are not based on neural network representations. And on Tuesday, I'm going to speak mostly about stuff that does depend on neural network representations. But I'm not sure where the boundary is going to fall. I've also invited Dr. Catherine Liao over there, who will join me in a question and answer session, an interview like we did a couple of weeks ago with David. Cat is a rheumatologist in the Partners Health Care System. And you'll actually be hearing about some of the work that we've done together in the past before we go to the interview. So roughly, the outline of these two lectures is that I want to talk a little bit about why we care about clinical text. And then I'm going to talk about some conceptually very appealing but practically not very feasible methods that involve analyzing these narrative texts as linguistic entities, as linguistic objects, in the way that a linguist might approach them. And then we're going to talk about what is very often done, which is a kind of term spotting approach that says, well, we may not be able to understand exactly everything that goes on in the narratives. But we can identify certain words and certain phrases that are very highly indicative that the patient has a certain disease, a certain symptom, that some particular thing was done to them. And so this is a lot of the bread and butter of how clinical research is done nowadays. And then I'll go on to some other techniques. So here's an example. This is a discharge summary from MIMIC. When you played with MIMIC, you notice that it's de-identified. And so names and things are replaced with square brackets, star, star, star kinds of things. And here I have re-replaced those with synthetic names. So Mr. Blind isn't really Mr. Blind. And November 15 probably really isn't November 15, et cetera. But I wanted something that read like real text. So if you look at something like this, you see that Mr. Blind is a 79-year-old white, white male. So somebody repeated a word with a history of diabetes mellitus in inferior MI who underwent open repair of his increased diverticulum on November 13 at some, again, that's not the name of the actual place, medical center. And then he developed hebatemisis. So he was spitting up blood and was intubated for respiratory distress. So he wasn't breathing well. So these are all really important things about what happened to Mr. Blind. And so we'd like to be able to take advantage of this. And in fact, to give you a slightly more quantitative version of this, Kat and I worked on a project back around 2010 where we were looking at trying to understand what are the genetic correlates of rheumatoid arthritis. And so we went to the research patient data repository of Mass General and the Brigham Partners Health Care. And we said, OK, who are the patients who have been billed for a rheumatoid arthritis visit? And there are many thousands of those people. And then we selected a random set of, I think, 400 of those patients. We gave them to rheumatologists. And we said, which of these people actually have rheumatoid arthritis? So these were based on billing codes. So what would you guess is the positive predictive value of having a billing code for rheumatoid arthritis in this data set? I mean, how many people think it's more than 50%? OK, that would be nice. But it's not. How many people think it's more than 25%? God, you guys are getting really pessimistic. Well, it also isn't. So it turned out to be something like 19% in this cohort. Now, before you start calling the fraud investigators, you have to ask yourself, why is it that this data is so lousy? And there's a systematic reason. Because those billing codes were not created in order to specify what's wrong with the patient. They were created in order to tell an insurance company or Medicare or somebody how much of a payment is deserved by the doctors taking care of them. And so what this means is that, for example, if I clutch my chest and I'm going to do a blood test, is that, for example, if I clutch my chest and go, oh, and an ambulance rushes me over to Mass General, and they do a whole bunch of tests, and they decide that I'm not having a heart attack, the correct billing code for that visit is myocardial infarction. Because, of course, the work that they had to do in order to figure out that I'm not having a heart attack is the same as the work they would have had to do to figure out that I was having a heart attack. And so the billing codes, we've talked about this a little bit before, but they're a very imperfect representation of reality. So we said, well, OK, what if we insisted that you have three billing codes for rheumatoid arthritis rather than just one? And that turned out to raise the positive predictive value all the way up to 27%. So you go, really? How could you get billed three times? Well, the answer is that you get billed for every aspirin you take at the hospital. And so, for example, it's very easy to accumulate three billing codes for the same thing, because you go see a doctor, the doctor bills you for a rheumatoid arthritis visit. He or she sends you to a radiologist to take an X-ray of your fingers, your joints. That bill is another billing code for RA. The doctor also sends you to the lab to have a blood drawn so that they can check your anti-CCP titer. That's another billing code for rheumatoid arthritis. And it may be that all of this is negative and you don't actually have the disease. So this is something that's really important to think about and to remember when you're analyzing these data. And so we started off in this project saying, well, we need to get a positive predictive value more on the order of 95%, because we wanted a very pure sample of people who really did have the disease, because we were going to take blood samples from those patients, pay a bunch of money to the Broad to analyze them, and then hopefully come up with a better understanding of the relationship between their genetics and their disease. And of course, if you talk to a biostatistician, as we did, they told us that if we have more than about 5% corruption of that database, then we're going to get meaningless results from it. So that's the goal here. So what we did is to say, well, if you train a data set that tries to tell you whether somebody really has rheumatoid arthritis or not based on just codified data, so codified data is things like lab values and prescriptions and demographics and stuff that is in tabular form, then we were getting a positive predictive value of about 88%. And we said, well, how well could we do by instead of looking at that codified data, looking at the narrative text in non-coded data?
